channel.title: Lets talk GLBots (I'm a complete moron :) )
channel.description:
So slightly curious on the subject I tried googling "runescape opengl bot" as I am 92 STR on a botted account and want to be 99.... To my dismay no opengl bots are public.
However I did run into GLIntercept, Installed it and was able to do this:
[IMG]http://i.imgur.com/fFvOD.png[/img] [img]http://i.imgur.com/nKEKO.png[/img]
without breaking a sweat (I used the downloadable Jagex client as I didn't know which JRE my firefox liked to use to place the DLL.)
Now I see GLIntercept has a handy plugin utility and I though great I will write something that can send the information to a Java application. Sadly I don't know what I am looking for to do this. I know it uses JNI but that's really as much knowledge as I have on the subject. /inb4 learn C++, java, OpenGJ
So I figured I would make this post and see if I can get any other input on the subject matter as I tried to hit up IRC to avoid the embarrassment of having to publicly post my stupidity. However the only one active in IRC at this time of ay appears to be <Tree>

item.title: Lets talk GLBots (I'm a complete moron :) )
item.dc:creator: @sspoke sspoke
item.description:
@sspoke wrote:

Hey you guys who are building openGL bots.

I just wanted to ask from that source code Miss Silabsoft posted.
The sys_glVertexPointer has a invalid pointer, it’s always 0 and sometimes 8 never anything you can reference to GLFloat x,y,z.

Then another problem

while (!NPCs.empty())
{
	drawNPC = NPCs.back();
	NPCs.pop_back();

	if(drawNPC.stride != draw_stride)
		continue;

	glPrint(drawNPC.x_s,drawNPC.y_s,1.0f,0.0f,0.0f,1.0f,"%u",drawNPC.id);
}

It gets the last element of NPCs vector and puts it into drawNPC then removes that element from the vector. So once the hashes are getting drawn on screen the NPCs vector is getting cleared.
It seems to only draw the hashes when I click on the screen too not always.

So… I’m just asking how did you guys get around that, if i never clear the NPCs vector and check for duplicates when entering new elements… I’d still get stuck with hashes which change on top of older hashes and other problems like never removing non-visible hashes.

I’ve attached the dll file,
the keys are
Numpad 5 to draw overlay,
Numpad 7 = view 12 stride,
Numpad 8 = view 16 stride,
Numpad 9 = view 24 stride.
Numpad 0 = increase stride count
Numpad .(dot) = reset stride to 0.

Read full topic
item.source: Lets talk GLBots (I'm a complete moron :) )

item.title: Lets talk GLBots (I'm a complete moron :) )
item.dc:creator: @The_Enforcer The Enforcer
item.description:
@The_Enforcer wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:178, topic:419600”][quote author=Speljohan link=topic=522145.msg3843334#msg3843334 date=1323426391]

[quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=522145.msg3842985#msg3842985 date=1323391787]

[quote author=the bank link=topic=522145.msg3842797#msg3842797 date=1323382432]

I guess that would be ‘cool’ if everything .NET wasn’t a steaming pile of garbage?
[/quote]it’s ridiculous how fucking close minded and obnoxious you are about everything

I’ve written some code in .NET languages before, like vb.net, j# and c#, and they were awful compared to Java. How is that close minded?
[/quote]I too don’t like .NET, but c# is a brilliant language.

Besides…whats the difference really between java and the “jvm” and .NET?

They operate under a similar concept, code compiled to bytecode, then interpreted/compiled to native code at runtime. But Java is cross-platform, open source, and can run applets in browsers and such. .NET can do none of those things, so you should either use Java, or write some native code.
[/quote].NET is cross-platform, but the compatibility isn’t exactly good at the moment. Also, Silverlight uses .NET, so that’s two of your three points debunked. Can’t argue with it being closed source though.

There is a huge difference in something actually being cross-platform, and something that ‘theoretically can be cross platform’. Java is maintained and supported by Oracle (previously by Sun) for all major platforms, that is where ‘compile once, run anywhere’ comes from. Microsoft only supports .NET under windows, and the open-source community driven Mono projects tries to make things work for other platforms. That’s not exactly what I would call cross-platform.

Anyone who hates C#/.NET is obviously a linuxfag who gets unjustified hardons when hearing the words ‘free’, ‘open-source’ and ‘cross-platform’.

Mopman put it better than I could. I can’t see any program or place where .NET could be used that some other language wouldn’t be better, either Java, or another language.[/quote]

Windows has 90% of total OS usage share, some people choose to develop for Windows - they really don’t mind Microsoft supporting .NET on Windows only. C# as a language is more feature rich than java, .NET offers more functionality than the java standard library. In terms of speed IL bytecode executes faster than java bytecode(even when on linux and using mono).

Now, when you’re trying to be cross-platform and you’re not writing toy programs you’re still at some point going to need to use some platform specific features. In this case java is the worst choice ever. It makes sense to use C++ with Qt and just compile for multiple targets.

Read full topic
item.source: Lets talk GLBots (I'm a complete moron :) )

item.title: Lets talk GLBots (I'm a complete moron :) )
item.dc:creator: @blupig blupig
item.description:
@blupig wrote:

Relax guys, this is a thread about GL bots, not some “Mac Vs. PC”-esque debate. We’ve all got our preferences, mine personally lie with C# and VB, and for others (especially for this type of thing) it’s Java and C++. I think it would be cool to see something scriptable in .NET, because then I’d actually be able to contribute to the project instead of waiting around like a noob like everyone on Sythe and elsewhere.

inb4 learn Java or C++, I did Java in highschool and am doing C++ in university, don’t like both.

Read full topic

item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Speljohan, post:174, topic:419600”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=522145.msg3842985#msg3842985 date=1323391787]

[quote author=the bank link=topic=522145.msg3842797#msg3842797 date=1323382432]

[quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=522145.msg3842140#msg3842140 date=1323316761]

I guess that would be ‘cool’ if everything .NET wasn’t a steaming pile of garbage?
[/quote]it’s ridiculous how fucking close minded and obnoxious you are about everything

I’ve written some code in .NET languages before, like vb.net, j# and c#, and they were awful compared to Java. How is that close minded?
[/quote]I too don’t like .NET, but c# is a brilliant language.

Besides…whats the difference really between java and the “jvm” and .NET?

They operate under a similar concept, code compiled to bytecode, then interpreted/compiled to native code at runtime. But Java is cross-platform, open source, and can run applets in browsers and such. .NET can do none of those things, so you should either use Java, or write some native code.
[/quote].NET is cross-platform, but the compatibility isn’t exactly good at the moment. Also, Silverlight uses .NET, so that’s two of your three points debunked. Can’t argue with it being closed source though.[/quote]

There is a huge difference in something actually being cross-platform, and something that ‘theoretically can be cross platform’. Java is maintained and supported by Oracle (previously by Sun) for all major platforms, that is where ‘compile once, run anywhere’ comes from. Microsoft only supports .NET under windows, and the open-source community driven Mono projects tries to make things work for other platforms. That’s not exactly what I would call cross-platform.

The Enforcer:

Anyone who hates C#/.NET is obviously a linuxfag who gets unjustified hardons when hearing the words ‘free’, ‘open-source’ and ‘cross-platform’.

Mopman put it better than I could. I can’t see any program or place where .NET could be used that some other language wouldn’t be better, either Java, or another language.
